text: how would you describe that the bones of
this agreement well I think it's a very
positive day for NHS patients and
actually for doctors as well from the
government's point of view we've got all
the red lines that we needed to improve
weekend care the the extra cost of
employing another doctor at the weekends
will fall by about a third under this
agreement which will make it much easier
for hospitals to improve care at
weekends and we've been to a system
where it's in return for a pay rise it's
agreed that doctors will work a certain
number of weekends a year at no extra
charge but I think we also have to
reflect that this has been a very bitter
dispute there are lessons to be learned
on all sides I think there was a message
in the industrial action that
unfortunately took place that there was
a lot of unhappiness amongst junior
doctors about things that weren't
necessarily to do with their contract to
do with the way their training operates
to do with the quality of life in those
very very tough jobs and we want to
engage positively and constructively to
address those issues because they are
the backbone of the NHS and you know I
do pay tribute to the leader of the
junior doctors Johan marijuana for
having the courage to negotiate on
weekend pay which is something the BMA
haven't been prepared to do previously
and has made this deal possible well
that there's a lot of interesting
content of that answered and thanks very
much sure but let's is setting up quite
a few things there can i pick you up on
a couple of them first of all this is
that the tough question to ask who's
given way here because frankly there was
no agreement or there was very little
agreement when you were approaching this
weekend roster the fact that you were
wanting to overall to have a smaller
bill to pay that that's the bottom line
isn't it so what happened in order to
make this agreement possible well I
don't want to talk about winners and
losers Hugh I hope you understand I mean
we we've got everything we needed for a
seven-day NHS and at least as far as the
junior doctors contract part of that is
concerned but we've also made some
concessions around the way that
maternity is done around more
flexibility in rostering things that I
no matter to junior doctors that I think
make this
agreement possible and I think what this
really shows is that if we sit around
the table and talk about issues that can
make care safer for patients and improve
the working conditions for doctors you
can have a win-win and I prefer to
characterize it that way okay well
you've mentioned there are lessons to be
learned on both sides let's explore that
then and can I ask you to give us an
open answer to this one what would you
do differently in the way that you
handle this delisa this was starting now
that you know now what you do know how
would you do things differently would
you well it's it's very difficult
because we had we have a manifesto
commitment to a seven-day NHS that we
absolutely must deliver to the British
people having been elected a year ago to
do that but I think what we didn't
understand at the start this process was
the amount of discontent amongst junior
doctors about things that were not
always to do with the contract about the
fact that you know you could be a junior
doctor who's posted to Leeds and your
partner is in London and it's very very
bad for family life if you're apart for
six months and there are lots of
frustrations like that which I think
came to a surface through the industrial
action that we've seen and I think that
this agreement that we now have which
has the support of the junior doctors
leader he's going to be encouraging his
own members to vote for it gives us a
chance to address some of those issues
but there'll be other issues as well
that we can look at and value the role
of junior doctors in the NHS and I want
to take the opportunity to do that but
forgive me for pressing stand I'm just
asking you know are you saying that you
have no regrets about the way you've
handled this dispute well I thought I
think the way to put this is you know we
have to implement manifesto commitments
I could be critical of the fact that
there was a very long period of time
when the BMA were refusing to talk at
all but I think the point is that on
both sides we've learned through the
process of the last ten days that
actually talking works much better and
it is possible to end with a win-win we
can deliver our manifesto commitment for
a seven-day NHS but also make real
progress in addressing some of the
concerns that junior doctors have had
about their working conditions and that
dialogue is the way to achieve these
things so I
it has been a very positive week when
will this new structure be in place and
up and running well we have to now have
a vote by junior doctors who will want
to consider very carefully what is the
biggest change in junior doctor contract
conditions for 17 years it's a very very
big change and they'll want to consider
it carefully but the agreement talks
about the new contract being implemented
from October this year and about a
12-month period before all junior
doctors have put on to the new terms and
conditions
